sn6.9:4.2: Now at that time the mendicant Kokālika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn6.9:4.3: Then, late at night, the beautiful independent brahmā Tudu, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the mendicant Kokālika,
sn6.9:4.4: and standing in the air he said to him:
sn6.9:4.5: “Kokālika, have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
sn6.9:4.9: “Didn’t the Buddha declare you a non-returner? So what are you doing back here?
sn6.9:4.10: See how far you have strayed!”
sn6.9:5.2: with an axe in his mouth.
sn6.9:5.3: A fool cuts themselves with it
sn6.9:6.1: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,
sn6.9:6.2: or criticize someone worthy of praise,
sn6.9:6.3: you choose bad luck with your own mouth:
sn6.9:6.4: you’ll never find happiness that way.
sn6.9:7.1: Bad luck at dice is a trivial thing,
sn6.9:7.2: if all you lose is your money
sn6.9:7.3: and all you own, even yourself.
sn6.9:7.5: is to hate the holy ones.
sn6.9:8.1: For more than two quinquadecillion years,
sn6.9:8.3: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,
sn6.9:8.4: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”
